title: Pattern Causality in a Large Dataset
text: ’ll use DJS dataset contains 29 stock price series - sufficiently large dataset analysis. First, let’s find optimal parameters analysis: Now can estimate pattern causality using optimal parameters: see three matrixs calculating. can visualize result plotMatrix function. positive status  negative status  dark status  see obvious positive connection system.
code: library(patterncausality) data(DJS) #head(DJS) dataset <- DJS[,-1] # remove the date column params <- optimalParametersSearch(   Emax = 3,    tauMax = 3,    metric = "euclidean",    dataset = dataset,   verbose = FALSE ) print(params) result <- pcMatrix(   dataset = dataset,    E = 3,           # Embedding dimension   tau = 1,         # Time delay   metric = "euclidean",   h = 1,           # Prediction horizon   weighted = FALSE  # Unweighted analysis ) print(result) #> Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis: #>  #> Number of items: 29  #>  #> Positive causality matrix: #>                        X3M American.Express     Apple    Boeing #> X3M                     NA        0.2261268 0.2224979 0.2565688 #> American.Express 0.2318415               NA 0.2198748 0.2522231 #> Apple            0.2283262        0.2680412        NA 0.2622407 #> Boeing           0.2507485        0.2711864 0.2869058        NA #> Caterpillar      0.2330168        0.2438080 0.2966432 0.3024545 #>                  Caterpillar #> X3M                0.2549020 #> American.Express   0.2511664 #> Apple              0.2674617 #> Boeing             0.2675737 #> Caterpillar               NA #> ... #>  #> Negative causality matrix: #>                        X3M American.Express     Apple    Boeing #> X3M                     NA        0.2421696 0.2406948 0.2295209 #> American.Express 0.2523844               NA 0.2480438 0.2174616 #> Apple            0.2592275        0.2353952        NA 0.2456432 #> Boeing           0.2649701        0.2397094 0.2243536        NA #> Caterpillar      0.2556611        0.2291022 0.2209212 0.2019002 #>                  Caterpillar #> X3M                0.2405732 #> American.Express   0.2192846 #> Apple              0.2248722 #> Boeing             0.2290249 #> Caterpillar               NA #> ... #>  #> Dark causality matrix: #>                        X3M American.Express     Apple    Boeing #> X3M                     NA        0.5317036 0.5368073 0.5139104 #> American.Express 0.5157740               NA 0.5320814 0.5303153 #> Apple            0.5124464        0.4965636        NA 0.4921162 #> Boeing           0.4842814        0.4891041 0.4887406        NA #> Caterpillar      0.5113221        0.5270898 0.4824356 0.4956453 #>                  Caterpillar #> X3M                0.5045249 #> American.Express   0.5295490 #> Apple              0.5076661 #> Boeing             0.5034014 #> Caterpillar               NA #> ... plot(result, "positive", asp = 1) plot(result, "negative", asp = 1) plot(result, "dark", asp = 1)

title: Pattern Causality in a Large Dataset

title: Introduction to patterncausality
text: First , can import data AAPL MSFT, also can import data yahooo api. can visualize stock price.

title: Introduction to patterncausality
text: search best parameters PC.
code: dataset <- DJS[,-1] parameter <- optimalParametersSearch(Emax = 5, tauMax = 5, metric = "euclidean", dataset = dataset)

title: Introduction to patterncausality
text: , calculate causality status. Lastly can also visualize result.
code: X <- DJS$Apple Y <- DJS$Microsoft pc <- pcLightweight(X, Y, E = 3, tau = 2, metric = "euclidean", h = 1, weighted = TRUE) print(pc) #> Pattern Causality Analysis Results: #> Total: 0.2755 #> Positive: 0.3997 #> Negative: 0.1521 #> Dark: 0.4482 plot_total(pc) plot_components(pc)

title: Introduction to patterncausality
text: details found following code. far, whole process algorithm finished.
code: X <- DJS$Apple Y <- DJS$Microsoft detail <- pcFullDetails(X, Y, E = 3, tau = 2, metric = "euclidean", h = 1, weighted = TRUE) # Access the causality components causality_real <- detail$causality_real causality_pred <- detail$causality_pred print(causality_pred)

title: Pattern Causality between two series
text: example, import climate patterncausality package. consider method cross-validation see robustness pattern causality. order make results better observed, provide plotCV function give line chart result.  can find causality keep position sample number large enough, method indeed captures hidden patterns causal connections sequences.
code: library(patterncausality) data(climate_indices) set.seed(123) X <- climate_indices$PNA Y <- climate_indices$NAO result <- pcCrossValidation(   X = X,    Y = Y,     numberset = c(100, 200, 300, 400, 500),   E = 3,   tau = 2,   metric = "euclidean",   h = 1,   weighted = FALSE ) print(result$results) #>          total  positive  negative      dark #> [1,] 0.2337662 0.4444444 0.1666667 0.3888889 #> [2,] 0.3220339 0.3157895 0.0877193 0.5964912 #> [3,] 0.2635379 0.2739726 0.3424658 0.3835616 #> [4,] 0.2732095 0.2912621 0.2330097 0.4757282 #> [5,] 0.2683438 0.2812500 0.2500000 0.4687500 plot(result)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wang H, Stavroglou S, Pantelous (2024). “patterncausality: Pattern Causality Algorithm R.” doi:10.2139/ssrn.4966221, Available SSRN, https://ssrn.com/abstract=4966221.
code: @Unpublished{,   title = {patterncausality: Pattern Causality Algorithm in R},   author = {Hui Wang and Stavros K. Stavroglou and Athanasios A. Pantelous},   year = {2024},   note = {Available at SSRN},   url = {https://ssrn.com/abstract=4966221},   doi = {10.2139/ssrn.4966221}, }

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: patterncausality package implements novel approach detecting analyzing causal relationships complex systems. Key features include:

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: Pattern-based causality detection State space reconstruction Multi-dimensional causality analysis Robust cross-validation methods

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: Financial market analysis Climate system interactions Medical diagnosis Ecological system dynamics

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: Detects nonlinear causal relationships Quantifies causality strength Identifies hidden patterns Handles noisy data effectively algorithm lot advantages. can find hidden pattern complex system. can measure causality different fields. can search best parameters complex system.

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: can install development version patterncausality GitHub : can also install package CRAN :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("skstavroglou/pattern_causality") install.packages("patterncausality")

title: Pattern Causality Algorithm
text: can import existing data. dataset contains 4 time series climate index, use patterncausality dataset. need determine E tao. course, can also change distance style calculate distance matrix. according combo produces highest percentages collectively, can choose best parameters . parameters confirmed, calculate pattern causality. percentages causality status displayed . examine causality status time point, can run following code: status series saved predict_status real_status.
code: library(patterncausality) data(climate_indices) head(climate_indices) #>         Date      AO    AAO   NAO   PNA #> 1 1979-01-01 -2.2328 0.2088 -1.38 -0.69 #> 2 1979-02-01 -0.6967 0.3563 -0.67 -1.82 #> 3 1979-03-01 -0.8141 0.8992  0.78  0.38 #> 4 1979-04-01 -1.1568 0.6776 -1.71  0.09 #> 5 1979-05-01 -0.2501 0.7237 -1.03  1.35 #> 6 1979-06-01  0.9332 1.7000  1.60 -1.64 dataset <- climate_indices[, -1] # remove the date column parameter <- optimalParametersSearch(Emax = 5, tauMax = 5, metric = "euclidean", dataset = dataset) X <- climate_indices$AO Y <- climate_indices$AAO pc <- pcLightweight(X, Y, E = 3, tau = 2, metric = "euclidean", h = 1, weighted = TRUE, tpb=FALSE) print(pc) #>       total positive  negative     dark #> 1 0.2841121 0.326087 0.2318841 0.442029 X <- climate_indices$AO Y <- climate_indices$AAO detail <- pcFullDetails(X, Y, E = 2, tau = 1, metric = "euclidean", h = 3, weighted = TRUE) predict_status <- detail$spectrumOfCausalityPredicted real_status <- detail$spectrumOfCausalityReal

K., Pantelous, . ., Stanley, H. E., & Zuev, K. M. (2020). Unveiling causal interactions complex systems. Proceedings National Academy Sciences, 117(14), 7599-7605. Stavroglou, S. K., Ayyub, B. title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
code: distanceMetric(x, method = "euclidean", ...)  # Default S3 method distanceMetric(x, method = "euclidean", ...)  # S3 method for class 'custom' distanceMetric(x, method, ...)

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
text: x Input data matrix vector method Custom function compute distances ... Additional arguments passed methods

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
text: distance object matrix containing pairwise distances

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
text: Generic Interface Distance Metrics

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
text: distanceMetric(default): Default method using stats::dist distanceMetric(custom): Custom distance metric implementation

title: Distance Metric Interface — distanceMetric
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Using default method x <- matrix(rnorm(100), ncol=2) d1 <- distanceMetric(x, "euclidean")  # Using custom method custom_dist <- function(x) as.dist(crossprod(x)) d2 <- distanceMetric(x, method=custom_dist) } # }

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
text: Analyzes pattern causality matrices classify nature causality variables. function provides core functionality pattern causality analysis can used independently part larger analysis workflows.

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
code: natureOfCausality(PC, dur, hashedpatterns, X, weighted = TRUE, verbose = FALSE)

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
text: PC Three-dimensional array; pattern causality matrices dur Numeric vector; time points analyze hashedpatterns Numeric vector; pattern identifiers X Numeric vector; reference output length weighted Logical; TRUE, uses weighted causality strength verbose Logical; TRUE, prints computation details

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
text: pc_nature object containing: no_causality: Vector causality strengths positive: Vector positive causality strengths negative: Vector negative causality strengths dark: Vector dark causality strengths

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
text: Nature Causality Analysis function analyzes structure pattern causality matrices determine four types causality: Causality: significant relationship detected Positive Causality: patterns show positive influence Negative Causality: patterns show negative influence Dark Causality: patterns show complex indirect influence

title: Nature of Causality Analysis — natureOfCausality
code: # \donttest{ # Generate example data PC <- array(runif(27), dim = c(3,3,3)) dur <- 1:3 hashedpatterns <- 1:3 X <- rnorm(10)  # Analyze causality nature result <- natureOfCausality(PC, dur, hashedpatterns, X) print(result) #> Pattern Causality Nature Analysis #> -------------------------------- #> No Causality: 0  #> Positive Causality: 0  #> Negative Causality: 0  #> Dark Causality: 3  # }

what: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
text: Searches optimal embedding dimension (E) time delay (tau) maximize accuracy causality predictions dataset. function implements grid search approach evaluate different parameter combinations.

title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
code: optimalParametersSearch(   Emax,   tauMax,   metric = "euclidean",   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   dataset,   h = 0,   weighted = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
text: Emax Positive integer > 2; maximum embedding dimension test tauMax Positive integer; maximum time delay test metric Character string; distance metric causality analysis ('euclidean', 'manhattan', 'maximum'). Defaults "euclidean". Ignored distance_fn provided. distance_fn Optional custom distance function; takes two numeric vectors input returns numeric distance. (default: NULL) state_space_fn Optional custom function state space reconstruction; takes numeric vector parameters E tau input returns reconstructed state space. (default: NULL) dataset Numeric matrix; column represents time series. h Positive integer; prediction horizon. weighted Logical; TRUE, weighted causality analysis performed. verbose Logical; TRUE, prints progress information. (default: FALSE)

title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
text: pc_params object containing: accuracy_summary: data frame summarizing accuracy parameter combination. computation_time: time taken analysis. parameters: list input parameters used.

title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
text: Search Optimal Parameters Pattern Causality Analysis function evaluates combination embedding dimension time delay effectiveness detecting different types causality: Total causality: Overall causal relationship strength Positive causality: Direct positive influences Negative causality: Direct negative influences Dark causality: Complex indirect causal relationships

title: Search for Optimal Parameters in Pattern Causality Analysis — optimalParametersSearch
code: # \donttest{ data(climate_indices) dataset <- climate_indices[, -1] optimalParams <- optimalParametersSearch(   Emax = 3,    tauMax = 3,    metric = "euclidean",   dataset = dataset,   h = 1,   weighted = FALSE ) print(optimalParams) #> Pattern Causality Parameter Optimization Results #> --------------------------------------------- #> Computation time: 13.903 secs  #>  #> Parameters tested: #>   Emax: 3  #>   tauMax: 3  #>   Metric: euclidean  #>  #> First few values: #>         E tau     Total  Positive  Negative         Dark #> Combo 1 2   1 0.5006373 0.4970317 0.5022991 0.0006691879 #> Combo 2 2   2 0.5009615 0.5015466 0.4962184 0.0022350584 #> Combo 3 2   3 0.5130561 0.5279035 0.4708467 0.0012498304 #> Combo 4 3   1 0.2824968 0.2719238 0.2576842 0.4703920280 #> Combo 5 3   2 0.2796224 0.2870213 0.2875241 0.4254546326 #> Combo 6 3   3 0.2944664 0.3240271 0.2823818 0.3935910495 #>  # }

what: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
text: Transforms signature matrix pattern space matrix processing row reflect categorical changes (increase, decrease, change) sequence values. changes hashed create unique pattern identifiers.

title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
code: patternSpace(SM)

title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
text: SM Numeric matrix; signature matrix row represents differences successive elements original time series data.  Must contain numeric values.

title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
text: numeric matrix row contains hashed pattern identifiers derived categorical changes signature matrix. Returns matrix NA values row contains NA values.

title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
text: Transform Signature Matrix Pattern Space Matrix function performs key steps: Converts numerical differences categorical changes (1: decrease, 2: change, 3: increase) Applies hashing function (detailed ) generate unique identifiers pattern Handles missing values returning NA rows containing NA values.

title: Transform Signature Matrix into Pattern Space Matrix — patternSpace
code: signatureMatrix <- matrix(c(1, -1, 0, 2, -2, 0, 1, -1, 0),                           nrow = 3, byrow = TRUE) patternSpaceMatrix <- patternSpace(signatureMatrix) print(patternSpaceMatrix) #>      [,1] #> [1,]  282 #> [2,]  282 #> [3,]  282

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
text: Evaluates causality prediction accuracy across multiple time series within dataset using PC Mk. II Light method. function analyzes pairwise causality relationships computes different types causality measures.

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
code: pcAccuracy(   dataset,   E,   tau,   metric = "euclidean",   h,   weighted,   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
text: dataset matrix data frame column represents time series E Integer; embedding dimension state space reconstruction (E > 1) tau Integer; time delay state space reconstruction (tau > 0) metric Character; distance metric use, one "euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum" h Integer; prediction horizon, indicating forecast distance (h >= 0) weighted Logical; whether use weighted approach calculating causality strengths distance_fn Optional custom distance function computing distances (default: NULL) state_space_fn Optional custom function state space reconstruction (default: NULL) verbose Logical; whether display progress information (default: FALSE)

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
text: object class "pc_accuracy" containing: parameters: List input parameters (E, tau, metric, h, weighted) total: Mean total causality across pairs positive: Mean positive causality across pairs negative: Mean negative causality across pairs dark: Mean dark causality across pairs matrices: Raw causality matrices type

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
text: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Accuracy — pcAccuracy
code: # \donttest{ data(climate_indices) data <- climate_indices[, -1] results <- pcAccuracy(dataset = data, E = 3, tau = 1,                       metric = "euclidean", h = 1,                       weighted = TRUE, verbose = TRUE) #> Analyzing causality relationships... #>  Analyzing relationships: 2/12 (17%) Analyzing relationships: 3/12 (25%) Analyzing relationships: 4/12 (33%) Analyzing relationships: 4/12 (33%) Analyzing relationships: 6/12 (50%) Analyzing relationships: 7/12 (58%) Analyzing relationships: 7/12 (58%) Analyzing relationships: 8/12 (67%) Analyzing relationships: 10/12 (83%) Analyzing relationships: 10/12 (83%) Analyzing relationships: 11/12 (92%) Analyzing relationships: 12/12 (100%) #>  #> Computing summary statistics... print(results) #> Pattern Causality Accuracy Analysis #> ---------------------------------- #> Parameters: #>   E: 3  #>   tau: 1  #>   metric: euclidean  #>   h: 1  #>  #> Causality measures: #>   Total: 0.2825  #>   Positive: 0.2773  #>   Negative: 0.2569  #>   Dark: 0.4657  #>  # }

what: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix

title: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix
code: pcCrossMatrix(   X,   Y,   E,   tau,   metric = "euclidean",   h,   weighted = TRUE,   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix
text: X Matrix data frame time series cause Y Matrix data frame time series effect E Integer; embedding dimension tau Integer; time delay metric Character; distance metric ("euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum") h Integer; prediction horizon weighted Logical; whether use weighted causality distance_fn Optional custom distance function state_space_fn Optional custom state space reconstruction function verbose Logical; whether print progress

title: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix
text: pc_matrix object containing causality matrices

title: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix
text: Compute Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis function performs key steps: Validates input data parameters Computes pairwise causality measures X Y Organizes results causality matrix Provides summary statistics causality type

title: Cross Pattern Causality Matrix Analysis — pcCrossMatrix
text: vars: Vector autoregression analysis tseries: Time series analysis tools forecast: Time series forecasting methods

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
text: Evaluates robustness pattern causality measures repeated sampling analysis. function performs cross-validation analyzing multiple subsets data assess stability causality relationships.

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
code: pcCrossValidation(   X,   Y,   E,   tau,   metric = "euclidean",   h,   weighted,   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   numberset,   random = TRUE,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
text: X Numeric vector; first time series Y Numeric vector; second time series E Integer; embedding dimension state space reconstruction (E > 1) tau Integer; time delay state space reconstruction (tau > 0) metric Character; distance metric, one "euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum" h Integer; prediction horizon (h > 0) weighted Logical; whether use weighted causality calculation distance_fn Optional custom distance function computing distances state_space_fn Optional custom function state space reconstruction numberset Numeric vector; sample sizes cross-validation random Logical; TRUE, randomly sample data points; FALSE, take sequential samples start (default: TRUE) verbose Logical; whether display progress information (default: FALSE)

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
text: object class "pc_cv" containing: samples: Vector sample sizes used results: Matrix causality measures sample summary: Summary statistics across samples parameters: List input parameters

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
text: Perform Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis function implements key steps: Validates input parameters data Performs stratified sampling time series data Computes pattern causality measures sample Aggregates results across samples

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
text: nonlinearTseries: Provides nonlinear time series analysis tools tseriesChaos: Offers chaos theory analysis methods rEDM: Implements empirical dynamic modeling techniques

title: Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Analysis — pcCrossValidation
code: # \donttest{ data(climate_indices) X <- climate_indices$AO Y <- climate_indices$AAO numberset <- c(100, 200, 300) result <- pcCrossValidation(X, Y, E = 3, tau = 1,                             metric = "euclidean", h = 2,                            weighted = TRUE, numberset = numberset) print(result) #> Pattern Causality Cross-Validation Results #> ---------------------------------------- #> Parameters: #>   Embedding dimension (E): 3  #>   Time delay (tau): 1  #>   Metric: euclidean  #>   Horizon (h): 2  #>   Weighted: TRUE  #>  #> Sample sizes: 100, 200, 300  #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>       total positive negative   dark #> mean 0.2585   0.2488   0.4908 0.2604 #> sd   0.0490   0.1361   0.1639 0.0447 #> min  0.2167   0.0936   0.3409 0.2291 #> max  0.3125   0.3475   0.6659 0.3116 #>  plot(result)  # }

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
code: pcEffect(pcmatrix, verbose = FALSE)

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
text: pcmatrix object class "pc_matrix" containing causality matrices verbose Logical; whether display computation progress (default: FALSE)

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
text: object class "pc_effect" containing: positive: Data frame positive causality effects negative: Data frame negative causality effects dark: Data frame dark causality effects items: Vector component names summary: Summary statistics causality type

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
text: Calculate Pattern Causality Effect Analysis function performs key steps: Processes raw causality matrices Computes received exerted influence component Calculates net causality effect (difference received exerted) Normalizes results percentage scale

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
text: vars: Vector autoregression multivariate time series lmtest: Testing linear regression models causality: Causality testing modeling

title: Pattern Causality Effect Analysis — pcEffect
code: # \donttest{ data(climate_indices) dataset <- climate_indices[, -1] pcmatrix <- pcMatrix(dataset, E = 3, tau = 1,                      metric = "euclidean", h = 1,                      weighted = TRUE) effects <- pcEffect(pcmatrix) print(effects) #> Pattern Causality Effect Analysis #> -------------------------------- #>  #> Positive Causality Effects: #>     received exerted   Diff #> AO     92.59   71.61  20.98 #> AAO    83.15  109.65 -26.49 #> NAO    71.51   64.57   6.93 #> PNA    85.56   86.98  -1.42 #>  #> Negative Causality Effects: #>     received exerted   Diff #> AO     71.12   78.40  -7.28 #> AAO    82.71   50.33  32.38 #> NAO    78.74   97.21 -18.46 #> PNA    75.75   82.39  -6.63 #>  #> Dark Causality Effects: #>     received exerted   Diff #> AO    136.29  149.99 -13.71 #> AAO   134.14  140.02  -5.88 #> NAO   149.75  138.22  11.53 #> PNA   138.69  130.63   8.06 #>  plot(effects)  # }

what: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
title: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
text: Implements advanced pattern causality algorithm explore causal relationships two time series datasets. function provides comprehensive analysis causality patterns, including state space reconstruction, pattern identification, causality strength evaluation.

title: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
code: pcFullDetails(   X,   Y,   E,   tau,   h,   weighted,   metric = "euclidean",   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
text: X Numeric vector; first time series data Y Numeric vector; second time series data E Integer; embedding dimension state space reconstruction tau Integer; time delay data points h Integer; prediction horizon causality analysis weighted Logical; whether weight causality strength metric Character; distance metric ('euclidean', 'manhattan', 'maximum') distance_fn Optional custom distance function computing distances (default: NULL) state_space_fn Optional custom function state space reconstruction (default: NULL) verbose Logical; TRUE, prints computation progress (default: FALSE)

title: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
text: pc_full_details object containing: backtest_time: Time points used backtesting valid_time: Valid time points analysis causality_real: Real causality spectrum causality_pred: Predicted causality spectrum state_spaces: State space reconstructions neighbors: Nearest neighbor information patterns: Pattern signature information matrices: Causality matrices predictions: Predicted actual values weighted: logical indicating weighted calculations used E: Embedding dimension used analysis

title: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis — pcFullDetails
text: Calculate Full Details Pattern Causality Analysis function implements key steps: State Space Reconstruction: Creates shadow attractors using embedding Pattern Analysis: Converts time series signature pattern spaces Nearest Neighbor Analysis: Identifies analyzes local dynamics Causality Evaluation: Computes predicted actual causality matrices Results Validation: Provides detailed diagnostics quality metrics

what: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
text: Implements computationally efficient version Pattern Causality Model Mk. II analyzing causal interactions two time series. function uses pattern signature spaces assess causality reconstructed state spaces hashed pattern analysis.

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
code: pcLightweight(   X,   Y,   E,   tau,   h,   weighted,   metric = "euclidean",   distance_fn = NULL,   state_space_fn = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
text: X numeric vector representing first time series Y numeric vector representing second time series E Integer; embedding dimension state space reconstruction (E > 1) tau Integer; time delay state space reconstruction (tau > 0) h Integer; prediction horizon future projections (h >= 0) weighted Logical; whether use weighted causality strength calculations metric Character string specifying distance metric; one "euclidean", "manhattan", "maximum" distance_fn Custom distance function state space reconstruction state_space_fn Custom function state space transformation verbose Logical; whether display progress information (default: FALSE)

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
text: object class "pc_fit" containing: total: Total causality strength (0-1) positive: Proportion positive causality (0-1) negative: Proportion negative causality (0-1) dark: Proportion dark causality (0-1)

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
text: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm function implements key steps: State space reconstruction using embedding parameters Pattern signature space transformation Nearest neighbor analysis reconstructed spaces Causality strength calculation using prediction accuracy Classification causality types (positive/negative/dark)

title: Calculate Pattern Causality Using Lightweight Algorithm — pcLightweight
code: data(climate_indices) X <- climate_indices$AO Y <- climate_indices$AAO result <- pcLightweight(X, Y, E = 3, tau = 1,                         metric = "euclidean", h = 2,                         weighted = TRUE, verbose = FALSE) print(result) #> Pattern Causality Analysis Results: #> Total: 0.3010 #> Positive: 0.2205 #> Negative: 0.3951 #> Dark: 0.3844 summary(result) #> Pattern Causality Summary: #>  #> Causality Strengths: #>       Type     Value #> 1    Total 0.3009709 #> 2 Positive 0.2204697 #> 3 Negative 0.3951284 #> 4     Dark 0.3844019 plot(result)

code: signatureSpace(M)

title: Calculate Signature Space Matrix from State Space — signatureSpace
text: M state space matrix row represents point state space

title: Calculate Signature Space Matrix from State Space — signatureSpace
text: signature space matrix row contains differences successive elements corresponding state space row

title: Calculate Signature Space Matrix from State Space — signatureSpace
text: Calculate Signature Space Matrix function performs following steps: Validates input matrix dimensions row, computes differences successive elements Returns transformed matrix maintaining number rows Similar functionality can found 'nonlinearTseries' package's embedding functions, implementation specifically tailored pattern causality analysis.

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
text: Reconstructs state space time series using delay embedding, creating matrix row represents point reconstructed space.

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
code: stateSpace(ts, E, tau, verbose = FALSE)

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
text: ts Numeric vector; time series data E Integer; embedding dimension (E > 1) tau Integer; time delay (tau > 0) verbose Logical; whether display progress information

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
text: object class "pc_state" containing: matrix: reconstructed state space matrix parameters: List reconstruction parameters original: Original time series data

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
text: State Space Reconstruction Analysis function implements Takens' embedding theorem reconstruct state space: Creates delay vectors using specified embedding dimension (E) Applies time delay (tau) consecutive elements Handles boundary conditions missing values

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
text: nonlinearTseries: Nonlinear time series analysis tseriesChaos: Chaos theory analysis tools fractal: Fractal analysis methods

title: State Space Reconstruction — stateSpace
code: ts <- c(1:100) result <- stateSpace(ts, E = 3, tau = 2) plot(result) #> Warning: no DISPLAY variable so Tk is not available

title: State Space Reconstruction Interface — stateSpaceMethod
code: stateSpaceMethod(x, E, tau, ...)  # Default S3 method stateSpaceMethod(x, E, tau, ...)  # S3 method for class 'custom' stateSpaceMethod(x, E, tau, method, ...)

title: State Space Reconstruction Interface — stateSpaceMethod

title: State Space Reconstruction Interface — stateSpaceMethod

title: State Space Reconstruction Interface — stateSpaceMethod
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Using default method x <- rnorm(100) s1 <- stateSpaceMethod(x, E=3, tau=2)  # Using custom method custom_space <- function(x, E, tau) {   list(matrix=embed(x, E)) } s2 <- stateSpaceMethod(x, E=3, tau=2, method=custom_space) } # }

Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max.  #>     100     125     150     150     175     200  #>  #> $causality_stats #>           total   positive  negative      dark #> mean 0.25918467 0.22490842 0.3477411 0.4273504 #> sd   0.05591705 0.04047246 0.1292482 0.1696621 #> min  0.19774011 0.17948718 0.2051282 0.2857143 #> max  0.30708661 0.25714286 0.4571429 0.6153846 #>  #> $convergence #>      total   positive   negative       dark  #> 0.05591705 0.04047246 0.12924816 0.16966206  #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "summary.pc_cv"

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Effect — summary.pc_effect
text: Invisibly returns input object.

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Effect — summary.pc_effect
code: # \donttest{ data(climate_indices) dataset <- climate_indices[, -1] pc_matrix_obj <- pcMatrix(dataset, E = 3, tau = 1,    metric = "euclidean", h = 1, weighted = TRUE,    verbose = FALSE) effects <- pcEffect(pc_matrix_obj) summary(effects) #> $effects_summary #> $effects_summary$positive #>       received   exerted          Diff #> mean 83.202119  83.20212 -3.552714e-15 #> sd    8.764969  19.95980  1.993609e+01 #> min  71.506182  64.57246 -2.649411e+01 #> max  92.589225 109.64732  2.098342e+01 #>  #> $effects_summary$negative #>       received  exerted      Diff #> mean 77.082125 77.08212   0.00000 #> sd    4.887857 19.58312  22.25668 #> min  71.124192 50.33220 -18.46447 #> max  82.707750 97.20834  32.37555 #>  #> $effects_summary$dark #>        received    exerted      Diff #> mean 139.715757 139.715757   0.00000 #> sd     6.942656   7.968076  11.83639 #> min  134.139041 130.631078 -13.70569 #> max  149.749949 149.992272  11.53075 #>  #>  #> $n_components #> [1] 4 #>  #> $strongest_effects #> $strongest_effects[[1]] #> $strongest_effects[[1]]$component #> [1] "AAO" #>  #> $strongest_effects[[1]]$effect #> [1] -26.49411 #>  #>  #> $strongest_effects[[2]] #> $strongest_effects[[2]]$component #> [1] "AAO" #>  #> $strongest_effects[[2]]$effect #> [1] 32.37555 #>  #>  #> $strongest_effects[[3]] #> $strongest_effects[[3]]$component #> [1] "AO" #>  #> $strongest_effects[[3]]$effect #> [1] -13.70569 #>  #>  #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "summary.pc_effect" # }

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Matrix — summary.pc_matrix
text: Provides summary pattern causality matrix object. function calculates displays descriptive statistics (mean, SD, min, max) causality matrix (positive, negative, dark).

code: # S3 method for class 'pc_matrix' summary(object, ...)

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Matrix — summary.pc_matrix
text: object pc_matrix object. ... Additional arguments passed summary function.

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Matrix — summary.pc_matrix
text: Invisibly returns input object.

title: Summarize Pattern Causality Matrix — summary.pc_matrix
code: data(climate_indices) dataset <- climate_indices[, -1] pc_matrix_obj <- pcMatrix(dataset, E = 3, tau = 1,    metric = "euclidean", h = 1, weighted = TRUE,    verbose = FALSE) summary(pc_matrix_obj) #> Pattern Causality Matrix Summary: #>  #> Number of items: 4  #>  #> Matrix statistics: #>              Type   Mean     SD   Min    Max #> Positive Positive 0.2773 0.1000 0.074 0.4471 #> Negative Negative 0.2569 0.0790 0.138 0.3660 #> Dark         Dark 0.4657 0.0494 0.402 0.5657
